title: England star Fran Kirby announces international retirement before Euros
body_text:
Fran Kirby has announced her retirement from international duty with immediate effect ahead of England’s European Championship campaign.
Just a month out from the Lionesses’ opening group-stage contest against France, Kirby outlined her intention to depart the international stage with her ‘head held high’.
The 31-year-old Brighton attacking midfielder has been instrumental in England’s progress over the last decade and was a key part of Sarina Wiegman’s squad that won the 2022 Women’s Euros.
But Kirby, who scored 19 goals in 77 appearances for her country, had been told she would not be included in Wiegman’s party for this summer’s tournament in Switzerland.
The news comes a week after Kirby’s long-time team-mate Mary Earps called it quits, with the PSG goalkeeper having lost her place to Hannah Hampton as Wiegman’s number one.
‘It is something I have been thinking about for over a year,’ Kirby told BBC Sport of her decision.
‘I knew this was going to be my last major tournament.

‘The plan was to retire after the Euros, but after speaking to Sarina, I’m not going to make the squad.
‘It was like a dagger to my heart but also a weight off my shoulders all at the same time.
‘It was emotional for both of us but we both respected what each person was saying.’
Kirby – who made her senior international debut in 2014 – played no part as the Lionesses missed out on a place in the Nations League semi-finals with a 2-1 defeat to Spain on Tuesday evening.
Facing the media shortly after the loss, Wiegman lifted the lid on her dialogue with Kirby in the lead-up to her retirement.
‘We’ve had several conversations and she’s been unlucky with injuries too during camps, but she always fought back and had some opportunities to play,’ she explained.
‘So yeah, I had conversations with her over this week again, going forward to this game [against Spain], and then I said to her that she most likely wasn’t going to make the Euros squad.
‘Things can change very quickly, but we had these honest conversations.’

Wiegman highlighted how Kirby had repeatedly managed to overcome setbacks in her career, describing the attacker as an ‘inspiration’ both as a player and a person.
Asked for her thoughts on Kirby as an individual, Wiegman added: ‘She’s an incredible footballer… her touch, her positioning, her vision, her game-understanding, her actions.
‘But as a person, what she has had in front of her and then coming back every time, that has been really incredible too.
‘She’s an inspiration for a lot of people and an example, absolutely.’
